boat.construction_details: Carvel - Larch on Elm, Oak and Iron Keel

for_sales.sales_text:
"Avola", the well known and much loved 33" one off Gaff Cutter, designed by J. Francis Jones and built by St Osyth Boatyard, Essex, 1965 is for sale. She was named after the town in Sicily where her original owner had landed with the 8th Army in 1943 during the Invasion of Sicily.

"Avola" is an excellent and very comfortable cruising yacht with accommodation for four adults. She sails well under her easily handled gaff rig and also has the benefit of a 50HP Nanni Diesel engine giving her a cruising speed of 7 knots. The spacious wheelhouse and the Kuranda Diesel heater combine to provide real four season usage. Sails include topsail, genoa and squaresail.

She is carvel planked in larch on steamed oak ribs fastened with copper nails and roves. Having the familiar Francis Jones flared bow with a slightly raked stem and an almost vertical transom; drawing 5.25" with an external ballast keel she is a remarkably stiff boat with a sea kindly motion both under sail and motor. Keel bolts replaced 2006.

She is offered complete with all equipment, winter cover, two dinghies, cutlery and crockery, cooking utensils, cooker with oven, hot water system and shower, four berths, chart table and galley, cabin table and wheelhouse table. Navigation equipment included comprising: Chartplotter with Navionics charts, AIS receiver, GPS, 2 x Sestrel compasses, echo sounder, trailing electronic log, radar, autohelm, navtex, VHF DSC radio.

Dimensions

LOA 36ft LOD 32.5", Waterline 26", Beam 9.67", Draft 5.25" long keel with deep forefoot.

Lying Ipswich Haven Marina

Full specification and description with numerous photographs.

boat.full_description:
'Avola' is a gaff rigged cutter with a good sailing performance. She has an inboard 50HP Nainni diesel engine with a cruising speed of 6 knots. The wheelhouse was added in the 1980s without having to make any alteration to the rig.

'Avola' cruises extensively in Northern Europe, the Baltic and Russia. At the Shipmate Classic Yacht Regatta in 2007 she won the prestigious Shipmate of Tradition Award.

Her name comes from a town in Sicily famous for its wine from Nero d’Avola grapes. At the invasion of Sicily on 10 July 1943 about 75 troops of the British 50th division of the 8th Army landed at Avola. The original owner was one of the first to set foot at Avola, and later named his boat to remember the occasion.

In 2015, 'Avola' celebrated her 50th birthday in style on both sides of the North Sea with the East Coast OGA and on a cruise in the Netherlands. OGA members may read about the cruise in the December 2015 and Spring 2016 Gaffers Log.
